Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Perform assigned physical tasks and material handling efficiently.
Situation2: A crane is holding a heavy beam in position, and you must immediately help guide it into place before it can be secured.
Story: I was standing at the edge of the construction site, sweat dripping down my back as the foreman barked orders. The crane operator shouted for me to help guide the heavy steel beam swinging above us. My gloves were already on, and I knew every second counted—if I didn’t move fast, the whole crew would be delayed, and the beam could become unstable. Just as I stepped forward, I caught a glimpse of my little brother on the sidewalk across the street, his head down, about to step off the curb without looking. My heart lurched. I was always the one who looked out for him, the one who promised Mom I’d keep him safe. But the foreman’s voice cut through my panic, demanding I get in position. I felt torn in two—my brother’s safety on one side, my responsibility to my crew on the other. My hands shook as I hesitated, caught between the urgent demands of both worlds, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
